20mm Plastic T-Slot - Rev 2
Completely redesigned; the new beam prints faster and is stronger both against deflection and torsion. UPDATE: Added DXF of Profiles. Naming convention is [dimensions]-[bolt size]-[Wall Thickness]-[Multiplier]. We are starting to prefer 1pt6 (1.6) wall thickness profiles and find printing them No Infill, 1 Extra Loop, No solid Layers, with a trace thickness of .8mm results in a quick and adequetly strong beam. These beams are being designed as the main structural component for a 3d printer though arguably they are of more use as a general hobby framing and mounting set. That said they are designed with both printing and commercial extrusion in mind. If printed in ABS, they can be solvent welded with the aid of a T-Slot Welding Jig http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13598 and ABS Glue http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14490 . A center hole increases the beams second moment of inertia while aiding in fusing beams. PLA beams are more rigid though they are not as easy to fuse into various lengths. Hardware
An example of Friction Fit hardware is located -
Here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9797
& Here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13599 The standard beam profile is meant to accommodate both M3 hardware as well as 6-32 nuts and bolts. Both bolt heads or nuts will fit in the slot with an insert provided to help guide and captive M3 nuts. 6-32 Nuts will captive natively. Alternative profiles are provided for M4 / 8-32 hardware as well as dedicated M3 and 6-32. All profiles are located in "20mm Profiles - Printing.skp" Use the 'Push/Pull' tool to create a profile of the desired length. If the printing instructions are followed, these beams can be printed fast (going at even a moderate pace we're able to produce all the beams needed for a Prusa in under 12 hours). While the beams can technically be printing with any working profile, they will not print as quickly and may not perform as intended structurally. Files
100mm Beam.stl - actual height is 101mm to allow for loss during welding
20mm Test Beam.stl - shorter for testing settings
M3 Nut Insert.stl - use with metric hardware
20mm Profile-Printing.skp - profile faces for printing and creating different heights
20mm Profile-True.skp - diagram of a properly printed profile
20mm Profile-Printing-pt4.skp - profiles based on 0.4mm widths, contains a M5 profile
M3 Nut Insert.skp - source file for insert Check Back For
T-slot Profiles for Thing-O-Matic, Ultimaker & Mosaic at various resolutions, speeds.
OpenScad version to ease design of compatible hardware and accessories.

READ ME!
These beams are designed with 2mm wall thicknesses to be printed with zero infill using consecutive loops of 1mm trace widths. There are also also a set of beams with 1.6mm walls for .8mm trace widths located in "20mm Profile - Printing - pt4.skp" though the standard profiles are more tested. When printing correctly, the nozzle will trace out 2 (3 for stronger) consecutive loops making a single jump as it jumps layer. The center hole is absent in the profile and created as an artifact of having zero infill. If you plan on printing many of these beams it will be worth your time to create a dedicated profile adjusting Flowrate (or what-have you for your skeinforge version) to give the best looking and strongest beams. General Tips
If you go to fast printing a single beam the print can start to mash about from overheating. Use a cooling fan or print multiple beams at once to give each layer time to cool. You can alternatively turn on the 'Cool' plugin to slow everything down...but who wants that, we're making T-Slot! It is possible for T-slot printed in a thingomatic to warp ever so slightly towards the back of the bot. If this happens, enclosing your bots open sides with board or tin foil will help. I have a piece of cardboard that clips to the Z-stage that shrouds to the front of the bot in much the same way as the z-stage shrouds to the back of the bot. This helps the most. If your nozzle is too low on the first layer you will get a small flange at the base of your beam. It can be taken off with a razor or better, change your Z-height slightly to give your nozzle a little more room for that first layer. Profiles are being put together for various printers and extruders for a more plug and play printing experience but the following should help you get setup making a dedicated profile. Settings ReplicatorG 27
1) Create New Profile
a. Top Menu: GCode > Edit Base Profiles...
b. Select the Profile you want to start from ie. SF35-Thingomatic-HBP-Mk7
c. Hit Duplicate and name something descriptive ie. T-Slot ABS
d. Your done! Skeinforge should open. If it does not, repeat steps 'a' and 'b' selecting your new profile and click the 'edit' button 2) Edit Toolpath
Top Menu: Gcode > Edit Base Profiles.. > 'Your new profile' / click 'edit'
Under 'Fill' tab - Extra Shells on Alternating Solid Layers = 1 (or 2, just be consistent)
Extra Shells on Base =1 (or 2)
Extra Shells on Spares Layers = 1 (or 2) Infill Solidity = 0 Solid Surface Thickness = 0 (I find this to make them look nicer)
Thread Sequence Choice = Perimeter - Loops - Infill 3) Adjust Width (if necessary)
Under 'Carve' -
Layer Thickness (mm) = 'Whatever your comfortable with, I use 0.3 so its a little faster than my standard 0.2 or lower) Perimeter Width over Thickness (ratio) = 1 / (the Layer thickness used previously) ie. If I used 0.3 for my Layer thickness, I perform 1 / 0.3 = 3.3333 This ensures that the perimeter trace width will be 1mm Under 'Fill' -
Infill Width over Thickness = The same value used in the previous step, in my case it would be 3.3333

author: rejaak

title: PlugPack Power Supply AC pins cover

description.text:
I do a lot of arduino projects and I've found that the little AC power to USB power supplies are a cheap and convenient way to provide 5V dc for the projects. I've made this little cover that goes over the AC input pins. Both PLA and ABS plastics are excellent electrical insulators. I wouldn't use the carbon fibre or flexi filaments. With regard to the plugpacks, I buy the ones with the US style pins. Then I attach some crimp on tab style connectors. This cover slips over to provide insulation and safety (refer safety notes below). WARNING : This thing is not weatherproof or designed to provide safety insulation. Only use it INSIDE another enclosure such as a project box. SAFETY : Don't mess with AC voltage. These little plugpack power supplies are of varying quality and price. Take some simple precautions to keep you and others safe:
  • If your device uses AC power, try to design everything so that there are no exposed metal parts that can be touched.
  • If you do have metal parts, make sure these are solidly connected to an earth from your power socket.
  • Connect the 5V negative (or 0V) to your AC Earth.
  • Make sure your house / office has it's power protected by RCDs.
  • Some of these little plugpack power supplies can get hot. Don't pack them in a little box. Give them some room for heat dissipation. Only load them to 50% of their rated capacity (e.g. if you have a 5V @ 1A supply, only load it to 1/2A.

This one was made with PLA.  Upside down orientation (flat bit on the bed) is probably best.  Make sure there are no sharp edges on the wire holes that may rub on the wires.  Attach to the power supply with a small amount of super glue or electrical tape.  
Don't mess with AC voltage.  Make sure you are qualified and know what you are doing.

This converts Ikea Samtid floor lamp to a corner wall mounted lamp; inspired by http://bit.ly/1ir5X6g It requires cutting the electrical cord for installation. Please read instruction.

Installation Steps

  • Print the corner mounts and its covers

  • Disassemble Samtid floor lamp into three parts: base, rod and upper arm.

  • Cut the electrical cord and pull the cord out of the rod and the base. I cut mine about 8 inches from the base of upper arm, so the patch area will be hidden in the rod after lamp is fully assemble.

  • Install the Top Corner Mount to the walls first.

  • Put the rod through the mounted Top Corner Mount and its cover.

  • Install the Bottom Corner Mount to the walls, then put on its cover.

  • Thread the electrical cord through Bottom Corner Mount and its cover all the way through the rod. Then solder the electrical cord back together. Make sure you don't mix positive with negative wires and use electrical tape to seal the patch area.

  • Mount the upper arm of lamp to the mounted rod by rotating the rod while holding the upper arm still.

  • Slide the rod back down, into the Bottom Corner Mount.

Designer inspired.

title: Compact Flash (CF) To 3.5" IDE adapter mount

description.text:
This is a bracket to install a CF->IDE adapter in an internal 3.5" hard drive bay.  I collect arcade games, some of which have hard drives.  Whenever possible, I replace the hard drives with a modern solid state drive (CF, SD, etc).  
If possible, I use a direct insert adapter, which plugs directly into the IDE header on the motherboard.  This is really convenient, as it doesn't require any additional mounting hardware.  Unfortunately, it's not always possible to use one of those adapters.  In this case, I replaced a 3.5" HD on a countertop Megatouch machine, which has the IDE header right near the rear lid of the machine, so there wasn't enough clearance.  So, I decided to make this bracket to allow mounting the CF adapter where the HD was previously mounted.  
I designed this for the Syba CF->IDE adapter, which I've used many times, and have had good luck with.  With a few minor modifications, it could probably work with other adapters (and other completely different applications) as well.  The mount has corners that hold the adapter near the IDE connector, and screw holes for a couple small M3 screws at the other end.  Since this is replacing a 3.5" drive, it also holds a HD to Floppy power adapter.  The holes on the side are sized for a typical 3.5" hard drive screw (6-32).  
I mounted this in the Megatouch, and it's running quickly, quietly, cooler, and should stay happy for a long time.

I printed this in ABS, using typical settings (0.3mm layer height, 10% infill, etc).
Once printed, I installed the adapter into the bracket. First slide the bottom edge under the corners. It sort of snaps into place with a little bit of force by pulling on the plastic that the soldered IDE header collides with. Then install the short M3 screws to secure the adapter in place.
If installing the power adapter, connect the floppy connector side first, and then press the HD side into the mount.
If you have a 6-32 tap, you can pre-tap the holes on the sides to make it easier to install, though you can easily just thread the holes by screwing directly into the plastic.

description.text: I've gotten significantly better results with this new slicing profile.  This profile is for ABS plastic.  To print with PLA I use the default slicing profile, cover the build plate with painter's tape, and change the build plate temperature to 20 degrees Celsius.

I use ReplicatorG. In ReplicatorG go to "Edit Slicing Profiles..." in the "GCode" menu. Select "Replicator slicing defaults" and click "Duplicate..." Enter a name for your new profile and click "Ok" The Skeinforge Settings window will open. Change all of your settings to match mine. "Support Cross Hatch" is optional. Try this on or off and see which works better for the types of things you print. When you are done changing your settings click "Save All" and close the window. Click "Done" in the "Edit Profiles" window. You can always edit your profile again later. Open the file you want to print and position it on the platform. Click "Generate GCode" and make sure that your new slicing profile is selected. Then enter your print settings. Object infill: 8%
Layer Height: .16mm
Number of Shells: 2
Feedrate: 40mm/s
Travel Feedrate: 55
Print Temperature: 225 Before you print click the "gcode" tab. Change
M109 S110 T0 (set HBP temperature)
to
M109 S115 T0 (set HBP temperature). [T0 uses right extruder, T1 uses left extruder] A great reference is wiki.bitsfrombytes.com/index.php?title=Skeinforge_Raft I have added kapton tape underneath the fans on the Makerbot Replicator. This reduces the amount of air being blown onto the print. I have taped paper over the openings on the sides of the makerbot. This helps to contain the heat.

description.text: My girlfriends insulin pump holder is constantly breaking... so I designed one she can print any time she needs!

Slicer: Cura 15.04.2 Printer Settings Printer: Robo 3D R1+ Filament: PLA Nozzle Diameter: 0.4mm Printer Speed: 50mm/s Layer Height: 0.2mm Shell Thickness: 1.2mm Top/Bottom Thickness: 1mm Infill: 25%, Grid Nozzle Temperature: 200C Bed Temperature: 50C Cooling: On 100% @ 0.4mm height. (I have dual 40mm fans with shrouds so this might be a necessary mod for easy support removal) Cooling Minimum Time: 25s Support Material Settings Support Locations: Everywhere Structure Type: Lines Infill: 15% X/Y Distance: 0.7mm Z Distance: 0.15mm Printing Instructions

  • In Cura, rotate both pieces of the model face down. This should fill the inside with support material. Trust me on this one.

  • Follow the above settings.

  • Print.

  • Remove support.

  • Lightly file the friction slider as needed. Make sure to take your time with this... lightly file, test fit. No good? Lightly file and test fit again. Repeat until the bottom piece fits snug.

description.text:
This is version 2 of my low profile tablet holder, the original is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724308 This is a big upgrade from the original with pretty much everything working the way that I want. comments.text:
There may be an issue with the pad parts on some printers. I'm, currently printing my third 'Left Pad'.
The issue is with the 'top' hole for the 'Spine'. Because the top edge next to it is 'detached' from the rest of the design for the first 2mm or so, it is very easy for it to break loose. This is made worse on some printers where the HPB can't properly maintain an even temperature all over. So these two parts needs to be printed with brims. (I can fit a 12 line brim on my Wanhao.)
The first failed print wasn't caused by this issue, though.(Nozzle clogged on me on the first... )

title: Luggage the Mimic
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Has a working lid hinge and latch, posable handlebars, feet, and optional "dentures!" Fill him with all of your lil treasures! Using Cymon's Hinged Treasure Chest as a base, I added everything else using Tinkercad, whew did that take a lot of time! I originally made the Mimic as a Halloween present (see photos) and noticed 3 problems:
1) the feet were a bit difficult to pry off the build plate
2) the legs were a bit easy to snap off
3) the hinge was difficult to snap on As quick fixes:
1) I created a luggageBotHollow with the feet hollowed out to reduce footprint size and make it easier to remove from the build plate. Each foot has more or less 2mm thick walls.
2) I thickened the connection between the legs and the box to make them harder to snap off.
3) I didn't fix 3. I always dislike friction-based hinges because they (eventually) wear out when printed in a soft plastic, and it is a little too difficult to snap into place in the first place. I can't be bothered to test out various tolerances to make it better though XP. If you do print, please let me know how it turned out with the quick fixes I made. My original came out well since I was careful, but I wanted my published version to be more oops!-proof and generally better designed. I also removed the personal engraving from the inside that the original in the photos had.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Normal (0.2mm layer height)

Infill:

your choice

Notes: Do High Resolution (0.1mm layer height) for the dentures. The mimic was designed to minimize overhangs and supports are built into the files. Rafts should not be necessary either.

ASSEMBLY Carefully remove the built in supports skirting the underside of the box and lid. I used a very thin application of brown acrylic paint using a toothpick to create the woody texture. You may need to shave a bit of the nubs on the hinge off or clear out the holes for the nubs to be able to snap the lid onto the rest of the chest. It is a very tight fit. A moderate application of heat to the PLA may also make it temporarily a little more pliant. The handlebars at their given size are nice and springy and easily squish into place on the sides. I recommend gluing the teeth carefully in place using Elmer's glue. Bigger teeth go on top! If done properly the teeth should slide by each other and the canines fit in holes in the box for them, so that the lid can be completely closed without any gaps. By using Elmer's glue, if you mess up you can just dissolve it in warm water and try again.

Print one of each file EXCEPT the luggageBot files. There are 2 versions, only print one of them. Print luggageBot if your printer has trouble sticking the first layer to the build plate. Print luggageBotHollow if your prints tend to print well to the build plate. (This version has hollowed out feet with ~2mm walls to minimize their footprint and make them easier to remove from the build plate.)   
I recommend printing everything in a nice gold or brown color except the dentures, which should be printed white. Mine was in yellow translucent PLA.

My wife wanted a toothbrush holder in our caravan, then drew up one =)
The holes for the toothbrushes are 20x20mm and 40x40mm toothpaste. Have not got my printer yet, so images on a printed coming.

This is a simple toothbrush rack I made. No glue needed for assembly (except for the screw hider for wall rack).   
I used a white 3 mm acrylic (Plexiglass). Thinner is not recommended for strength concerns and clear acrylic material is not recommended because it gets water stains very quickly.  
Included are cut-ready pdf's (with kerfing) for 3mm acrylic, source Corel Draw and a test file.  
If you are going to use different thickness material I suggest you do some test cuts first to test the fit of the parts. A test file is included with instructions inside. You should have a snug fit without any slack.  
The stand: two center pieces for stability, the right side rests are slightly higher than the left (as the curve of most toothbrushes).  
The wall-mounted rack: one screw in the middle was enough for me. The right side, again, is slightly elevated. Below the main parts are some spacers and (rightmost two) a screw cover you'll need to glue on (permament, hides the screw if ugly, optional).

This is our first product "Smart Laser Mini"
The Smart Laser Mini is an open source, easy to assemble type of laser cutter and engraver. It is completely do it yourself for example you can make engraving marks on many kinds of surfaces and you can even use this laser to cut on many kinds of materials.
The Smart Laser Mini uses simple mechanisms, making it easy to assemble. Also this laser cutter is compact in size therefore perfect for household use. http://www.smartdiys.cc/

Details of Smart Laser MIni My friend Hirotaka and I worked hard to develop an affordable easy to use desktop laser cutter for about one year. Then finally, our ideas and effort were fully realized. -Open source
People can be freely modify our software and hardware to expand the processing area and add such as adding additional functions. -1.6 watts diode laser
It adopted 1.6 watts diode laser for the laser parts. The output is strong enough that it can cut 0.079inch (2mm) of material. -Mechanical parts.
We adopted open builds V-slot (http://openbuildspartstore.com/) for our mechanical parts, therefore it is simple and easy to assemble. -Computer software
Computer software works on the Browser. It’s producing by HTML, JavaScript, Python and this is Cross-platform. You can use with Windows、Max OS X、Lunux、Raspberry Pi.
  • The control board
    The control board used Arduino Mega.
    (Arduino - ArduinoBoardMega2560)
    Arduino Mega’s program is based on GRBL (Bengler: GRBL)
    • ・Laser
    For the Laser diode, we use Blue Laser Diode 1.6 W in TO56 Package by OSRAM Ltd. http://www.osram-os.com/Graphics/XPic1/00088311_0.pdf/PL TB450B.pdf Laser diode is cooling by the heat sink and fan, also it reduces the tempersture rise of the laser diode. And, ｔhe cover for blocking the light of the laser are mounted on the laser module. Download Data file http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1026345/#files ・Axises
    Smart Laser Mini’s axises are OpenBuilds’s V-Slot Linear Rail(20 x 20mm)とDelrin Mini V Wheel. By adopting V-Slot, the number of parts will be reduced and the mechanism will become simple. http://openbuildspartstore.com/v-slot-linear-rail/ http://openbuildspartstore.com/delrin-mini-v-wheel/ ・Acrylic parts
    Smart Laser Mini is used 5mm thickness acrylic for marerials such as Plates. Download Data file
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1026345/#files ・Motors
    Use 3pcs of NEMA17 Stepping motors(JK43HS34) Arduino Mega Arduino - ArduinoBoardMega2560 A4988 drivers Pololu - A4988 Stepper Motor Driver Carrier Smart Laser Mini Shield designed using the KiCad. KiCad EDA Download Smart Laser Mini Shield’s design data file from GitHub. ・KiCad data files ・Circuit diagram (pdf) ・Parts list smartDIYs/SmartLaserMiniShield · GitHub ・Firmware
    The controller software is based on the GBRL (Bengler: GRBL) which modified the Lasersaur (Lasersaur Manual). The computer and controller are connected via COM (USB), and the communication is working by G-Code. ・PC Software PC Software also based on Lasersaur. It made by Python, HTML and JavaScript therefore It can work in a variety of platforms such as Windows, Mac and Linux. This PC software is Server-client system. Start the server software on the PC that you want to work on and start a browser session as a client on the same PC to access the server software. Also, it is possible to perform server and client software on different PCs and control them through the Internet. The software on the server side is created based on the light Web framework Bottle of Python. The software on the client side is created in HTML and JavaScript. ・Software Download
    Download Smart Laser Mini’s software from GitHub smartDIYs/SmartLaserMini · GitHub ・Work data
    As for the Smart Laser Mini, there are two types of working techniques.
  • The vector cutting
    • The vector cutting can cut along the outer shapes also It can be created in SVG or DXF format. 2.The raster engraving　 Raster engraving is for impressing an image while horizontally scanning just like filling. Raster engraving can be put into practice by pasting SVG, PNG or BMP format images. ・Work with Raspberry Pi Smart Laser Mini also works with Raspberry Pi. As you can see the following blog, we mounted Raspberry Pi 2 and 7inch monitor to the Smart Laser Mini. ・Raspberry Pi 2 , Monitor and Desktop Laser Cutter ・Facebook Group
    We created a Japanese pubric group called “ Share your work using the Smart Laser Mini” The group members post and share own work in Facebook. We will create in English version soon. http://www.facebook.com/groups/1630210010590821/ ・Composition of the Smart Laser Mini ・Controllers It built 2pcs of A4988 drivers dedicated shield to the Arduino Mega. It called “Smart Laser Mini Shield” Built Smart Laser Mini Shield to the Arduino Mega

title: Volkswagen Bus / Westfalia / Campervan Fresh Air Vent Cover

description.text: This is a vent cover for the Bay Window T2 VW Van fresh air vent intakes that normally go through the door armrests to the rear seats. I have replaced my door panels and removed the armrest/air vents, and without something to block the outlets on the lower fresh air vents no fresh air would come out of the dashboard vents. With no backpressure, all of the air comes out of the lower vents, which is unacceptable. With these covers installed, you create backpressure and get fresh air out of the dash vents again! These are side-specific, so print one for the left side, and one for the right side. Check out my blog for how I have used the 3D printed objects on my VWs at: https://stupidbus.wordpress.com/

description.text:
Work in progress
Apologies for the mess! Four versions of FPV camera mounting/protection for the superb Fossils Stuff Gravity 250/280 (1) cam_mount_v_1_3
10degree rise, fits most 32mm board cameras (usual suspects: Sony super HAD 600tvl etc)
[this is a design by another designer not me, modified slightly for my purposes, unfortunately I don't have the name and source] (2) 25deg_gravity_camera_housing_board_cam_vz11
my 25deg rise version of the board camera housing (1) (3) Working_camera_mount_v02
15deg casing to protect mini cameras such as the sony 1177 and the Runcam SKy (26mm case) - does not hold the camera as such, the camera needs to be fixed to the Gravity frame as per usual) (4) Working_camera_25_deg_for_mini_cam_mount_v002_mount_v03_fixed
as item (3), but with a 25degree rise. all are to be taken as is / work in progress, some are tested lots some still work in progress ( I have printed and flown version 1 - 3, version 4 is printed and out for trial!

title: Schnaps Seilbahn / Cable Car delivering Shots

description.text: UPDATE a new Version is online: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1748449 Ein Schnapsseilbahn von der Bar auf die Bühne zum 20jährigen Jubiläum einer Musikkapelle. Die Bahn konnte von der Bühne und von der Bar aus ein- und ausgeschaltet werden. A Cable Car delivering Shots from the Bar Area onto the Stage for the Musicians. Developed for a 20th Aniversary of a Band https://youtu.be/NoVG3bZymYg

Für die Aufhängung der Rollenbatterie verwende ich M8 Gewindestangen mit Kontermuttern, für die Rollen M5 Schrauben. Das Tragseil ist eine einfache Wäscheleine, gummiert, mit Stahlkern (ca. 3,5mm Durchmesser)
Die Umlaufräder der Bar- und Bühnenstationen sind ausrangierte Speichenräder von Kinderwagen mit gedruckten Buchsen für M6 Schrauben. 
Die Gondelklemmen werden mit einfachen 3x7mm Blechschrauben zusammengeschraubt, die Schnapsgondeln bestehen aus alten PC-Slotblechen und einem gedruckten Ring.
Es war mein erstes 3D Projekt mit Freecad, daher habe ich manches wohl umständlich konstruiert... Jedenfalls hats funktioniert ;-)
I used M8 treaded rods and M5 Screws and Nuts for the roll batteries. The cable is a simple rubber coated steel wire normaly used for a washing line (is this the right term in english?) with a 3,5mm diameter.
The big Bar- and Stage-station wheels ar from an old baby stroller.
For the clamps i used 3x7mm self-tapping Screws together with old PC slot brackets and the Plastic Ring for the shot Glasses.

Make your 3D printer play music. Using the sounds a printer motor makes naturally its possible to convert a song into G-code that tells the printer to move along its axes in a way that creates a song. The provided G-code is for the Pokemon theme song. Here's a link to a demonstration video:
https://youtu.be/NbvSmlTS5o4

• Under the slicer configuration settings go to printer settings.
  • Under printer settings, select custom G-code.
  • Here you will insert the G-code on the next line after G28.
  • Save, and name the printer setting Pokemon.
  • Now when you load an object to print and are ready to slice it select Pokemon as your printer setting in the Slic3r menu.
  • Once you select start print the printer will home all axes and then begin playing while your extruder warms up! Before the song plays it will go to its starting position to verify the print bed dimensions. Once the song is done it will re-home all axes and then begin your print.
    • Note:
    The instructions demonstrate the use of this code using Repetier and Slic3r. I don't know how well it will work on other platforms. Caution:
    This code was generated to the dimensions of a printrbot simple's print bed. Given that this is a small four by four inch print bed there shouldn't be any points in the code that is out of range for most printers ,however, I do advise that you use it at your on risk. I would also like to give credit to HomeConstructor for the software I used to convert MIDI to g-code. Here is a link:
    http://en.homeconstructor.de/converter-convert-music-in-g-code.html

Wire all the LEDs in Parallel instead of going for Series, use a voltage regulator appropriate for the way you wire them then.
Depending on the colour LEDs you want to use - 3.0 to 3.2 should work really well running of a 18650 cell (3.7V - remember though its generally fully charged to 4.2V)

title: 3 turn helix antenna 1.28 GHz for FPV

description.text:
So this is my version of a 3 turn helix antenna for my FPV setup. As coil I'm using 2mm  stainless steel welding rods. And the reflector i got from a stove burner cover. :-P it's only 0.2mm so i made a reinforcement as you can see in the files. 
Edit: This is a RHCP holder. If you need a LHCP you just have to mirror it.
Edit2: The stainless steel rod where to hard to solder so I took some galvanized steel wire 2mm instead.
Edit3: added some tools to make it easier to roll the helix. they are for a LHCP so if you need a RHCP just mirror it ;-)

I modeled the helix coil from the data i got in the calculator found here http://jcoppens.com/ant/helix/calc.en.php and used that model to cut out holes in the holder to get a perfect match for the wire. This was made in fusion 360

title: Rubberband powered counter rotating flying machine

description.text: while this is only a simplistic model, its like i envision these as a more elegant way for thing needing to function at higher altitudes (cell phone towers, for example) rather than an ugly not very well hidden tower a slow flying electrically powered version of this could lift itself into the air and become a more integrated part in the landscape is it moves, constantly unlike the static towers currently existing.

To have this function correctly you will need either a bearing (approximately, doesn't have to be exact) of around 22mm nor more than 24, and a rubber band. the bearing will be used to aid in smooth rotation for the two sides, and the rubber band will simply be attached to either side and when ready to test fly, be twisted. the last parts you'll need are some (as straight as possible) skewers, or you can edit the file on Tinkercad to make it fit to any other sort of wings you can think of.

description.text: Scanned with ReconstructMe and an Xbox Kinect at the Coney Island Scan-A-Rama booth at Danbury Makerfaire on Saturday June 8, 2013. It was the public debut of my new scanning rig- the Scan-O-Tron 3000, and the scans have been beautiful. I am about to kick off a Kickstarter for Scan-A-Rama and plan to open source my plans, so stay tuned. Coney Island Scan-A-Rama is a next generation portrait studio for the 21st century! In the grand tradition of amusement part portraiture, but updated for the era of 3D printing, this popup 3D portrait studio will be appearing at MakerFaires and in Coney Island throughout 2013. For more information or to order prints, please visit http://www.thegreatfredini.com/scan-a-rama I recommend printing at .27 or .1 mm layer height with no support. You may have to trim a couple bits of hanging plastic off, but this will look great with no support.
simple puzzle

Make your 3D printer play music. Using the sounds a printer motor makes naturally its possible to convert a song into G-code that tells the printer to move along its axes in a way that creates a song. The provided G-code is for the This is Halloween theme song form the movie Nightmare Before Christmas. Here is a link to a demonstration video:
https://youtu.be/lxYLczpPw20

• Under the slicer configuration settings go to printer settings.
  • Under printer settings, select custom G-code.
  • Here you will insert the G-code on the next line after G28.
  • Save, and name the printer setting This is Halloween.
  • Now when you load an object to print and are ready to slice it
    select This is Halloween as your printer setting in the Slic3r menu.
  • Once you select start print the printer will home all axes and then begin playing while your extruder warms up! Before the song plays it will go to its starting position to verify the print bed dimensions. Once the song is done it will re-home all axes and then begin your print.
    • Note:
    The instructions demonstrate the use of this code using Repetier and Slic3r. I don't know how well it will work on other platforms. Caution:
    This code was generated to the dimensions of a printrbot simple's print bed. Given that this is a small four by four inch print bed there shouldn't be any points in the code that is out of range for most printers ,however, I do advise that you use it at your on risk. I would also like to give credit to HomeConstructor for the software I used to convert MIDI to g-code. Here is a link:
    http://en.homeconstructor.de/converter-convert-music-in-g-code.html

title: Leaf Lamp
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The leaf lamp is intended to be placed by the door to provide a dim illumination when returning home. The bowl shape serves as a catchall for keys, change and cell phones.
I'm using an arduino uno to pulse the LED's, sometimes in combination with a proximity sensor to adjust the maximum brightness.
Thanks to clothbot for the idea of using aluminum foil as both a ground plate and a reflective surface.

• Print all parts in white plastic, with zero infill (to allow the light to spread throughout the piece better) and glue or bond together.
  • Cut a piece of aluminum foil to the shape of the leaf.
  • Form foil to the bottom of the leaf, shiny side in, and poke holes in line with the LED holes.
  • Place (or glue) LED's in holes and bend ground leads down to contact foil.
  • Using tape or any other method, secure ground leads to foil.
  • Tape over entire surface of foil with electrically insulating tape (I used kapton and it looks really nice).
  • Bend positive leads down flat with taped surface.
  • Wire in whatever way you see fit (I wired 8 of the LED's in pairs, and the remaining 6 in threes, including the resistors on the bottom of the leaf, to make them fit with the 6 pwm pins on my arduino).
  • Cover with another layer of insulating tape.
  • Glue edges of foil to bottom of leaf
  • Wire and program LED controller

author: jdamsbo

description.text:
Make your 3D printer play music. Using the sounds a printer motor makes naturally its possible to convert a song into G-code that tells the printer to move along its axes in a way that creates a song. The provided G-code is for the Sail by Awolnation song. Here's a link to a demonstration video:
https://youtu.be/iJWcV0SoGLY

• Under the slicer configuration settings go to printer settings.
  • Under printer settings, select custom G-code.
  • Here you will insert the G-code on the next line after G28.
  • Save, and name the printer setting Sail.
  • Now when you load an object to print and are ready to slice it select Sail as your printer setting in the Slic3r menu.
  • Once you select start print the printer will home all axes and then begin playing while your extruder warms up! Before the song plays it will go to its starting position to verify the print bed dimensions. Once the song is done it will re-home all axes and then begin your print. This is a long song so if you want to cut it short only insert a portion of the G-code to play to the length you want.
    • Note:
    The instructions demonstrate the use of this code using Repetier and Slic3r. I don't know how well it will work on other platforms. I've noticed when loading the .nc file if you copy and paste into your custom g-code sometimes the code is too long and will not paste all at once. It may take copy and pasting portions of code into the custom code a few parts at a time. Caution:
    This code was generated to the dimensions of a printrbot simple's print bed. Given that this is a small four by four inch print bed there shouldn't be any points in the code that is out of range for most printers ,however, I do advise that you use it at your on risk. I would also like to give credit to HomeConstructor for the software I used to convert MIDI to g-code. Here is a link:
    http://en.homeconstructor.de/converter-convert-music-in-g-code.html

author: jdamsbo

description.text:
Once I get to the bottom of a roll of filament i can't print for more than an hour without it jamming as the end of the roll has a tight coil on the filament and this kept causing the extruder to jam. So i designed this quick fix.  
It makes sure that the filament going into the extruder is nice and strait. Since I've had this on I've not had a single print jam!  
I'm using a Robo3D printer, as far as i know the Greg's wade on there is the same as any other but let me know if I'm wrong.
Just print it, but some 4mm bowden tube in and trim it to size. It should be a very tight fit so make sure it doesn't come loose during a print.

title: 19mm Alu Square Tubing Threaded Rod Z Axis Motor Mount for the Smartrap Core

description.text:
Z Axis motor mount for 19mm alu square tubing. This is for people using 19mm or 3/4" aluminum square tubing to build their Smartrap Core. This is based on Djinn's Heavy Duty Threaded Z part.
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/smartrapcore-heavy-duty-z Print this then print the top idler and Z sled. Rods as per your calculated value for the build height you've picked. To mount this onto the aluminum tubing there are two counter bored holes for some M4x60 bolts. Use M4 washers if possible. Use the part as a guide to mark your holes then drill and tap the holes into the alu square tubing. 1/8 drill bit works well to tap alu. A small tap with a punch helps align your drill bit on your mark. EDIT 10/19/2015 Okay after actually installing these I need to update the install instructions a bit. First once you get the part aligned on the alu tube. Just use your 1/8 drill bit to drill down the hole of the part into the tube. That ensures great alignment. Tap as before. Also use an M4x50 bolt not 60 as it is too long. Other than that it works great! I will upload some additional build photos soon.

comments.text: I would like to adapt this to the 13mm rail for the HK13 SmartrapCore, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1050574 Can we have to cad file?
comments.author: ear0wax

author: jhslwood

description.text:
This is a quick little set of modules that I made in openscad to quickly generate dovetails to join two objects together.
Hopefully these will be useful to someone...
The included STL file is just a sample of the output.

There are 3 relevant modules: male_dovetail(max_width=11, min_width=5, depth=5, height=30, cutout_width=5, cutout_depth=3.5)
This produces a male dovetail with the dimensions specified. The cutout_width and depth specify the dimensions of a cutout in the center of the dovetail that will hopefully provide some spring or flex to allow them to go together tightly. female_dovetail((max_width=11, min_width=5, depth=5, height=30, block_width=15, block_depth=9, clearance=0.25)
This produces a block of the specified dimensions with a dovetail cut out of it with an added clearance on three sides. female_dovetail_negative(max_width=11, min_width=5, depth=5, height=30, clearance=0.25)
This produces the negative of the above module so that you can subtract it from an object.

Make your 3D printer play music. Using the sounds a printer motor makes naturally its possible to convert a song into G-code that tells the printer to move along its axes in a way that creates a song. The provided G-code is for the Ghostbusters theme song. Here's a link to a demonstration video:
https://youtu.be/oZ8qpGXvuGo

• Under the slicer configuration settings go to printer settings.
  • Under printer settings, select custom G-code.
  • Here you will insert the G-code on the next line after G28.
  • Save, and name the printer setting Ghostbusters.
  • Now when you load an object to print and are ready to slice it select Ghostbusters as your printer setting in the Slic3r menu.
  • Once you select start print the printer will home all axes and then begin playing while your extruder warms up! Before the song plays it will go to its starting position to verify the print bed dimensions. Once the song is done it will re-home all axes and then begin your print. This is a long song so if you want to cut it short only insert a portion of the G-code to play to the length you want.
    • Note:
    The instructions demonstrate the use of this code using Repetier and Slic3r. I don't know how well it will work on other platforms. I've noticed when loading the .nc file if you copy and paste into your custom g-code sometimes the code is too long and will not paste all at once. It may take copy and pasting portions of code into the custom code a few parts at a time. Caution:
    This code was generated to the dimensions of a printrbot simple's print bed. Given that this is a small four by four inch print bed there shouldn't be any points in the code that is out of range for most printers ,however, I do advise that you use it at your on risk. I would also like to give credit to HomeConstructor for the software I used to convert MIDI to g-code. Here is a link:
    http://en.homeconstructor.de/converter-convert-music-in-g-code.html
